Gatineau woman dies after police called to her apartment, watchdog reports
A Gatineau woman who was handcuffed by police and then taken to hospital has died, one day after the series of events that began with a noise complaint.
The woman was identified by the coroner’s office on Thursday as Nadia Racine, 34, of Gatineau.
Quebec’s Bureau des enquêtes indépendantes, which examines instances of death or serious injury involving police, is investigating and says it will give only a few details about the case.

The bureau says Gatineau police went to an apartment on Charles Albanel Street on Tuesday evening after neighbours complained of noise and someone shouting. They found the woman “agitated and delirious,” and say she had a head injury.

They initially handcuffed the woman, but shortly afterward officers realized her condition was deteriorating and they called an ambulance. She was taken to hospital.
The bureau has not released any information about the nature of her injury or the cause of her death.

Racine’s cousin, Jenn Knox, said the story that has so far emerged about her relative’s arrest and death is “very bizarre.” Knox said Racine had a beautiful spirit, and would go to great lengths to help people.
“She helped me a lot in my own sad and dark moments,” she said. “She was a spiritual, funny person who helped everyone around her and loved animals.”
